        Marc Bodnick

        Start by following him.
        The sheer variety of topics he votes on is staggering. If you follow him, you will be exposed to tons of good answers and posts on Quora, which will help you find your own favorites among the people who crop up regularly in your news feed.

         He also upvotes good content regardless of who wrote it, which means that even after you start following Top Writers and other Quora luminaries (Farwa Naqvi has mentioned some cool people), you will still get content from promising new users.

        Adam Nyhan, homo sapienshomo sapiens         Suggest Bio
        Votes by
        Lisa Groeneweg,
        Rupert Baines,
        Geoff Gilleland,
        Stephanie Vardavas, and 23 moreLoading....
        I suggest following any person whose demographic group -- age, country of location, racial/ethnic background, religion, political views, occupation, sexual orientation -- differs from yours, because that suggests they may have insights different from your own in some way.

        Yes, this sounds somewhat tokenistic: follow this Black Lesbian and you'll learn everything that all Black Lesbians think about everything!  No, of course not - you're just getting a peek into that one individual's views.

        But membership in any one of these demographic communities does tend to give one insights that others may not acquire, and I'm interested in thinking of things in new ways.  So I routinely follow people solely because they live in another country, are much older or younger than me, hold a job I know nothing about, are a faithful member of any religion, etc.  This has shown me some of the more interesting content in my feed.

        Here are some quality answerers who have yet to be recognised.
        • Jonathon Green.  Joined in January 2011.  He is a professional lexicographer of English slang, arguably the world's best according to the Independent[1], and writes amazing answers about the origins of slang words and phrases.
        • James Mcfeley.  He writes great answers for lots of questions about home repair and maintenance.
        • Jeff Scheuer.  He's a mattress expert and former Olympic luge coach.  Seriously, this is like a dream come true: two subjects you never thought you'd meet experts on covered by one marvelous man!
        • Chuck Eesley.  Stanford professor in Management Science & Engineering with long, comprehensive, and well-informed answers on questions about entrepreneurship and technology innovation.
        • Jonathan Kang.  CPU Design Engineer at Qualcomm with lots of detailed answers about same.
        • Scott Frey.  Orthodontic resident with lots of great answers on dental and orthodontic issues.

        The best list of people on Quora formally recognised in the real world for their domain expertise can be found here: Who are some people on Quora who really know their field of expertise?

        I'm going to mention a couple people who I don't see already in people's answers:

        Ben Thomas always gives amazing, thorough answers (with pictures!) on neuroscience and linguistics. Each of his answers is more akin to a magazine article than an ordinary Quora answer.

        Joshua Engel consistently gives solid, detailed, and accurate answers on pretty much everything.

        Ori Barbut is a great source on physics. He derives all his answers from first principles and puts in the equations, with diagrams.

        Alex Stoll is the best source for any questions about things that fly that aren't birds. If you like airplanes, follow Alex. He also plays a mean guitar.

        OK, so my approach to this question is going to be "how do I find quality people to follow on Quora", not "who are some quality people on Quora".

        And that's easy to see with some simple Google search operators (for more info,  see https://support.google.com/webse...).

        Let's create a list of Quora users that have some minimum follower count and are related to my market/industry. It will only take a second.

        Let's say my industry is SEO. Which Quora users related to my industry have at least 1,000 Quora followers?

        Go to Google and search for this:
        site://www.quora.com/  SEO "Followers 1000.."

        To break down the above search, what I'm asking Google for is:
        *(site://www.quora.com) = limit search to all the pages in Quora.com
        *(SEO) = pages that are relevant for the term "SEO"
        * ("Followers 1000..") = pages with more than 1,000 followers

        Play around with the search term and follower counts (read more about how to search by number range in the link to Google support that I posted at the beginning).

        You can trick this search out in a lot of different ways and I'd love to see examples from other users.

        Ari Shahdadi, ..         Suggest Bio
        Votes by
        Michael Litman,
        Rebekah Cox,
        Matthew Carroll,
        Brandon Smietana, and 12 moreLoading....
        In addition to Marc's comprehensive list, I'll throw in a non-comprehensive list of a few of my favorites:

        • Brandon Smietana.  Asks lots of really awesome questions on finance, stats, machine learning, and always has punchy, insightful answers.
        • Jon Bischke.  Very knowledgeable about startup stuff, and also a great person to follow on health/fitness related questions.
        • Viksit Gaur.  Asks and follows really interesting questions.
        • Sasha Katsnelson, Ani Ravi, Eunji Choi.  Great crew to follow, all of them are hitters when they answer questions.
        • Jessamyn West.  Valuable experience from being a librarian and moderator on MetaFilter, very thoughtful answers.
        • Quora Admins.  Following each the admins will give you a good overview on what's going on generally with the site, and you'll see really insightful and well-written answers from them as well.  Big ups for the admin team. 
        • Kim-Mai Cutler.  Not super active, but her answers are awesome when she pops in.
        • Elad Gil.  Great answers and a lot of valuable insight into entrepreneurship.
        • Richard Price.  I am consistently impressed by the number and quality of the questions he posts.
